awd_titl_txt: Assessment of Hurricane Marias impact and subsequent effects of ecosystem regeneration and heavy metal inputs in an urban coastal wetland
awd_abstract_narration:
The Nation Science Foundation-supported Center for Innovation, Research and Education in Environmental Nanotechnology at the University of Puerto Rico - Rio Piedras is dedicated to the development of nanomaterials and devices to address environmental pollution, while developing a diverse science, technology, engineering and mathematics workforce.  The Center's research endeavors include development of nanomaterials for water purification, soil remediation, and resource recovery. 

Center investigators submitted a Rapid Response (RAPID) proposal to the National Science Foundation to conduct quick-response research on a natural disaster. The combined paths of Hurricane Irma on September 6, 2017, and Hurricane Maria on September 20, 2017, had devastating effects across the entire island of Puerto Rico. The urban coastal wetland that serves as the Center testbed, source of substrates for nanostructure development, and substrate for biofuel production, was severely affected by the hurricane winds, and by massive flooding due to fresh water flowing from upland sources.

Center research staff at the University of Puerto Rico Rio Piedras will (1) assess hurricane impact and subsequent wetland regeneration: the substrate source for nanostructure construction, substrate source for biofuel generation, and the plant species to be used in combination with nanostructures for nano-phyto remediation work, and (2) quantify the heavy metal inputs to the testbed wetland.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: 
Proposed research will contribute to knowledge concerning the impact of extraordinary natural climatological events, such as a massive hurricane and the subsequent climatological conditions in the area, impact regeneration dynamics of an urban coastal wetland system, and its capacity for heavy metal remediation. 

BROADER IMPACT: 
Proposed work will advance discovery and understanding of how massive hurricane impacts affect coastal wetlands under a framework of urban and industrial conditions. Project activities provide hands-on training and learning, by involving graduate and undergraduate students in research. The project will broaden the participation of under-represented groups in science technology, engineering and mathematics fields.

por.por_cntn:
Hurricane Maria, September 20, 2017, had devastating effects across the entire island of Puerto Rico. The urban coastal wetland Cienaga Las Cucharillas, on the western side of the San Juan Bay in Puerto Rico was affected by hurricane winds and massive flooding by freshwater from the Malaria Channel and sea storm surge. We took advantage of this experiment made by nature to a) assess hurricane impact and subsequent regeneration of the wetland, b) quantify the elemental inputs to the wetland via the Malaria channel that brings fresh water from the surrounding areas, and 3) determine the water sources to the system and uptake by plants using the natural abundance of δ18O. The research enhances understanding of coastal urban wetlands and provides significant information to policy makers, government agencies and community groups to make science-based, well designed management decisions in these areas.

 

 

Plant functional types in the wetland showed resilience to initial hurricane effect and changes associated to posterior changes in conductivity and freshwater availability. The successional pattern of plant regeneration varied according to conductivity (salinity) and freshwater availability in the spatio-temporal mosaic. Wetland substrate saturation, primary dependent on the climatic conditions and the very sporadic use of the water outflow pumps at the mouth in the San Juan Bay, maintains it as a nitrogen sink, where ammonium is the primary source for plant growth. Plant cover increases the sink capacity of the system. The eutrophic nature of the wetland based on high nitrogen isotopic values substrate and leaves and high nutrient availability, coupled with pH dependent phosphorus bioavailability, increased the speed of regeneration of the area.  As tropical coastal wetland soils are a P sink, increased availability can increase the productivity, biomass and faster recovery of the system after a major catastrophic event.

The spatio-temporal mosaic is acting as a sink for transition metals. Given that soils typically build slowly in wetlands, high concentrations of Zinc and Pb reflect the historical and contemporary sources (urban, military and industrial) in the microbasin. Even after fifty years the legacy of the terrestrial inputs to the wetland in the higher bioavailability of Copper, Zn and Pb where mineral soil interspersed within the organic matrix, brought as landfill in the 1950-1960's is still present. Increase in rainfall extremes where drought conditions are becoming the norm rather than the exception, higher air temperatures and increased evapotranspiration can reduce and maintain a lower phreatic level. The expansion of oxidizing rather than reducing conditions could shift the wetland from a sink to a source of nutrient and elemental pollutants into the bay.

 

Water temperature in the Malaria Channel, the integrated source of freshwater to the wetland from the microbasin, ranged daily from 27°C to 35°C.  Higher water temperatures lower dissolved oxygen and increase conductivity as reflected in the diel changes on both parameters. Nitrate concentrations were very low with pulses of up to three orders of magnitude throughout the years, the latter most likely nutrient input by point sources. Ammonium diel levels were under the 100 mg/L-N, where wide diel fluctuations probably reflect the weather instability and inputs from the wetland. The peak after a dry period, nearly one order of magnitude in late mid-March 202, in both wetland phreatic water and channel water confirms the wetland-channel connectivity.

 

Natural abundance of δ18O and δD from the wetland water sources have significantly distinct signals: seawater > in-situ precipitation > water from the Malaria Channel which vary according to climate, precipitation, and local conditions. At phreatic level the signals reflect in-situ precipitation in areas farther from the channel. Wells nearer to the channel reflect the constant subsurface lateral flow towards the wetland, while the others reflect the deep subsurface marine input in the system.

 

Plant functional type species variations in the natural abundance of δ18O and δD.  Herbaceous species, Typha domingensis, had a significantly higher positive signal than the other species indicating uptake of evaporated water from the soil surface and/or brackish water from the surficial soil. Laguncularia racemosa, white mangrove, signal reflects the surface freshwater dependence of this species. Our results also showed changes between wet and dry periods where during a dry period all plants uptake water with heavier isotopes than during wetter periods confirming the more evaporated nature of the water source. In August 2020Tropical Storm Isaias passed over our island leaving behind a lot of rain, which shows in our results since the water was more depleted in the heavier isotopes, characteristic of the “Amount effect” in precipitation. Determining the water dynamics in a coastal wetland using this methodology may indirectly help the rehabilitation and management of these ecosystems as it can give an overview on how the hydrology of coastal wetlands is changing due to regional climate change and sea level rise.
